newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada gets Bre-X fraud complaints, stock delisted.
newsitem.headline: Canada gets Bre-X fraud complaints, stock delisted.

text.p: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police said Wednesday they received two fraud complaints involving Bre-X Minerals Ltd. and its Busang gold bust as investors tallied up their losses from history's biggest gold swindle.
While investigators met Wednesday to decide their next move in a widening probe over the gold fiasco, the Toronto Stock Exchange delisted the former stock market darling.
In a letter to the RCMP, Bre-X Chief Executive David Walsh alleged a fraud had been perpetrated against his company, but he did not identify a suspect.

A second fraud complaint was filed by the Ontario Securities Commission (OSC), Canada's top securities regulator. The Ontario Securities Commission is conducting its own investigation of Bre-X for possible violations of insider trading and disclosure laws.
Bre-X officials were unavailable to comment on Wednesday.
Under Canadian law, a fraud conviction can carry a maximum 10-year prison sentence, said Don Holmes, a forensic accountant with Ernst & Young consultants.
"In spite of Bre-X laying a complaint with the RCMP, the company itself could be held criminally liable. That would involve showing that its officers and directors perpetrated a fraud," Holmes said.
Bre-X announced on Wednesday the resignation of two directors from the boards of Bre-X and its sister firms.

The Busang discovery in Indonesia -- touted by Calgary, Alberta-based Bre-X as the richest gold find of the century -- was falsified on a scale "without precedent in the history of mining," according to a report by consultant Strathcona Mineral Services Ltd. released late Sunday.
Since then Bre-X's stock -- once valued at over C$6 billion ($4.4 billion) -- has collapsed to pennies a share and class action suits loom over the embattled miner.
The Toronto Stock Exchange (TSE) on Wednesday delisted Bre-X shares after it concluded that "the company no longer meets the required listing standards."
Bre-X closed up one-half cent at 9 cents Canadian (6 cents) cents Wednesday on 20 million shares on the TSE.

Deleen Schoff, a spokeswoman for the RCMP in Alberta, denied a report from Indonesian police on Wednesday that an RCMP team would arrive in Jakarta either on Thursday or Friday to question people involved in the Busang affair.
"At this point anything is possible, but we haven't designated anyone to go over (to Indonesia)," Schoff said. "We haven't decided if we're going over."

The Alberta government has named a special prosecutor to work with the RCMP. "He'll work very closely with the police, assisting them and providing them with legal advice," Leslie Gronow, a spokeswoman for Alberta's Justice Ministry, said.
While police met over the Busang imbroglio, there was increasing speculation over how much and when Bre-X officials knew about the tampering of core samples from Busang.
Strathcona said there were several red flags in reports that Bre-X received last year from Canada's Kilborn SNC-Lavalin Inc. and Australia's Normet Pty Ltd.
Strathcona said Bre-X's storage warehouse near the Borneo town of Samarinda, where core samples were kept for a lengthy period of time, was the most likely spot for any tampering.
Published reports from Indonesia have quoted local Bre-X employees as saying that they blended reddish, white and gold-coloured powders with pulverized rock samples from Busang.
Analysts said Bre-X officials either did not recognise or ignored the clues contained in the Kilborn and Normet reports.

Before Sunday's announcement, Walsh had dismissed doubts about Busang that had dogged his company since March. Walsh has said he was shocked by Strathcona's report and investigators hired by Bre-X would find the culprits.
Bre-X's chief of exploration, John Felderhof, also has expressed dismay over the tampering at Busang and denied any knowledge of the fraud.
Felderhof has gone into virtual seclusion at his $2.9 million estate in the Cayman Islands. Cayman immigration officials said Felderhof had applied for permanent residency.
As Canada's financial sector totalled up their losses from the Busang blowout, Canadian newspapers on Wednesday were filled with the hard-luck stories of Bre-X shareholders.
An estimated C$500 million ($362 million) was lent to people to buy Bre-X shares and they now must pay it back.
Toronto-based investment dealer First Marathon Inc., the most active Canadian brokerage in Bre-X, said on Wednesday it lost C$4.5 million ($3.2 million) on the meltdown.
The mayor of Edmonton, Alberta, has threatened to fire the city official reponsible for losing almost C$750,000 ($540,000) from the city pension fund due to Bre-X.
